title: Praise and God's Sovereignty
shortSummary: Psalm 135 is a call to praise the LORD for His goodness, sovereignty, and mighty acts on behalf of Israel. It highlights God's unique relationship with His people, His power over nature and nations, and contrasts the living God with lifeless idols. This chapter encourages worship and trust in the LORD alone.
timeline: c. 1000 BC - United Monarchy period, likely during or shortly after the reign of David or Solomon

keyCharacters.name: Jacob
keyCharacters.description: The patriarch chosen by God, representing the nation of Israel as His treasured possession.

keyCharacters.name: Israel
keyCharacters.description: God's peculiar treasure and chosen people, recipients of His promises and blessings.

keyCharacters.name: Pharaoh
keyCharacters.description: The Egyptian ruler who opposed God’s people and suffered plagues and judgments as described in the Exodus.

keyCharacters.name: Sihon and Og
keyCharacters.description: Kings of Amorites and Bashan defeated by God to give their lands to Israel.

definitions.definition: A special possession; in biblical context, it refers to Israel as God's chosen and treasured people.
Miraculous signs and miracles performed by God to demonstrate His power and authority.
Man-made images of silver or gold worshiped by heathen nations, which are lifeless and powerless.
God’s compassionate act of relenting or showing mercy towards His servants.

outline.heading: Call to Praise the LORD
outline.description: The psalmist invites all servants of the LORD, especially those in His temple, to praise His name for His goodness and pleasantness.

outline.heading: God’s Choice of Israel and Sovereignty
outline.description: God’s special selection of Jacob and Israel is affirmed, along with His supreme power over creation and nature.

outline.heading: God’s Mighty Acts in History
outline.description: Recounting God’s judgments on Egypt, mighty kings, and nations, culminating in the gift of their land to Israel.

outline.heading: God’s Eternal Name and Justice
outline.description: The LORD’s name endures forever; He judges His people and shows mercy to His servants.

outline.heading: The Futility of Idols
outline.description: A contrast is drawn between the living God and the powerless idols made by human hands, warning against trusting them.

outline.heading: Final Call to Bless the LORD
outline.description: The houses of Israel, Aaron, and Levi are called to bless the LORD, concluding with praise from Zion.

application: Regularly offer heartfelt praise to God, recognizing His goodness and sovereignty in all areas of life.
Trust in God’s power over all circumstances, remembering His mighty acts on behalf of His people.
Reject reliance on worldly idols or false sources of security, placing full confidence in the living God.
Remember God’s mercy and justice, seeking to live as His faithful servants who honor His name.

keyVerses.text: Praise the LORD; for the LORD is good: sing praises unto his name; for it is pleasant.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the fundamental reason for worship—God’s inherent goodness and the joy found in praising Him.

keyVerses.text: For the LORD hath chosen Jacob unto himself, and Israel for his peculiar treasure.
keyVerses.significance: It affirms God’s special covenant relationship with Israel as His treasured possession.

keyVerses.text: Thy name, O LORD, endureth for ever; and thy memorial, O LORD, throughout all generations.
keyVerses.significance: This verse declares the eternal nature of God’s name and His enduring presence across generations.

keyVerses.text: They that make them are like unto them: so is every one that trusteth in them.
keyVerses.significance: A powerful warning that those who trust in idols share in their futility and blindness.
